title: 107_hr613
content: The "Character Learning and Student Success Act of 2001" (CLASS Act of 2001) grants funds for developing and promoting character education initiatives. Character education in schools focuses on improving students' character by teaching ethical values and virtues, promoting a compassionate and responsible society. It involves social, emotional, and ethical development through positive character traits in the regular school curriculum. Effective character education boosts students' self-esteem and reduces the risk of negative behaviors. Character education in schools emphasizes the social, emotional, and ethical development of students by teaching positive character traits. It increases self-esteem, reduces negative behaviors, and fosters core ethical values and virtues in students. States and local educational agencies are increasingly promoting character education initiatives. Successful implementation requires integration into existing curriculum and daily activities. An increasing number of States and local educational agencies are promoting character education initiatives, which require access to effective methodologies, high-quality initiatives, professional development opportunities, criteria for assessment, and cost-effective networking options. The implementation of character education in schools requires a central source of information on the activities and effectiveness of initiatives at the federal, state, and local levels. The Secretary is authorized to grant a 5-year grant to an eligible organization with expertise in providing national-level support for character education. The Secretary is authorized to make a 5-year grant to an organization with expertise in character education policies, initiatives, and curricula. The organization must have a representative membership and a commitment to promoting quality character education initiatives. The grant recipient must develop initiatives that address core ethical values, emphasize student motivation and behavior, help create caring school communities, allow students to practice character lessons, and involve families. The grant recipient must focus on student motivation, behavior, and character development, including leadership, service, and teamwork. They should involve families and communities in character education and evaluate its effectiveness. Grant funds will be used for information dissemination. The grantee must focus on character education initiatives, including methods of assessment and integration into educational content. Grant funds will be used for information dissemination on quality character education initiatives and professional development models. The grantee will use funds to provide a searchable database with information on character education groups, curricula, books, and initiatives, as well as a checklist for schools to assess character education programs. The grantee will provide a searchable database with information on character education groups, curricula, books, initiatives, and videos, a checklist for schools to assess programs, an index of character education websites, and telephone assistance. An annual report must be submitted to the Secretary detailing progress and the number of information requests received. The grantee must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing progress in implementing character education requirements, including the number and types of information requests received, identifying future information needs, and providing a detailed account of grant fund usage. $750,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006 for this purpose. SEC. 3. GRANT TO CONDUCT CHARACTER EDUCATION RESEARCH. Congress finds that states and local educational agencies have received Federal funding for character education initiatives in schools, but there are minimal reporting requirements on their impact. The number of schools implementing these initiatives, their success, and the needs of schools already implementing them are unknown. Efforts should be made to assess the extent and effectiveness of character education in schools. Efforts should be made to assess the extent and effectiveness of character education initiatives in schools. The Secretary is authorized to make a single 5-year grant to an eligible organization with expertise in evaluation, research, conceptual understanding of character education approaches, and experience in developing such initiatives in schools. The Secretary may award a 5-year grant to an eligible organization demonstrating expertise in evaluation, research, character education approaches, developing initiatives in schools, identifying quality programs, publishing research, and having a partnership with a higher education institution. The grant recipient must assess schools' implementation of character education initiatives. The grant recipient must assess schools' character education initiatives, including evaluating outcomes and funding sources. The grant recipient must evaluate the effectiveness of character education initiatives in schools and submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing research progress, results, future needs, and fund usage. Authorization of $700,000 is provided for this purpose. The grant recipient must evaluate character education initiatives in schools, submit annual reports on research progress, results, future needs, and fund usage. Authorization of $700,000 is provided for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "eligible organization" as a tax-exempt organization under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code that has submitted a grant application to the Secretary. It also defines "local educational agency" as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education and must provide information as required. The term "local educational agency" is defined under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, while "school" includes elementary and secondary schools as defined in the same Act.
